byline.original: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, ABBY GOODNOUGH and JESS BIDGOOD

abstract: Bostonians express ambivalence upon hearing that Boston Marathon bomber Dzhokhar Tsarnaev was sentenced to death; many city residents, surprisingly, opposed death sentence, with some saying they believe life in prison would be worse than death, since Tsarnaev is only 21 years old; while some feel death penalty is a strike against liberal underpinnings of city, many survivors of the bombings express relief.
lead_paragraph: To many Bostonians, the death sentence given to Dzhokhar Tsarnaev on Friday felt like a blot on the city’s collective consciousness.

headline.main: Death Sentence for Boston Bomber, Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, Unsettles City He Tore Apart
headline.print_headline: Death Penalty Leaves Boston Unsure of Itself

snippet: To many Bostonians, the death sentence given to Dzhokhar Tsarnaev on Friday felt like a blot on the city’s collective consciousness.
